bibl.title: Despatch from Alexander G. Clark to William F. Wharton, December 13, 1890
Despatches from United States Consuls in Monrovia, 1852-1906

correspAction.roleName: U.S. Minister Resident and Consul General

div1.p: No 7 Dispatch Consular Series, Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia December 13th 1890 Alexander Clark to Department of State
Subject
Receipt from the Department of state and other Inclosures
No 7 Dispatch Consular Series, Legation of the United States Monrovia Liberia December 13th, 1890 To the Honorable William F. Wharton, Assistant Secretary of State Wasington D.C.

Sir: I have the honor to respectfully acknowledge the recpt from the department of state the following U.S. 1. copy diplomatic and consular series of the United States for October 20th 1890: 2 copies no 4 series of 1890 statement of debt of the United States for the month of October 1890: 3. copies Hydrographic department of the Navy: 3. Copies United States coast and geodetic Survey no 133 to Marines for the month of October 1890 (inclosure)
Inclosures
No 1 needed furniture and fixtures for the legation 2. Inclosure rain heat sickmen 3. Inclosure.
Most respectfully Remain your obedient servant Alexander Clark Minister Resident & Consul General of United States

No 1 Inclosure needed furniture and fixtures viz: sofa; looking glassl washbole and pitcher; carpet and rug; lamp and buckets one small stove for a stove aught to be kept in the Legation room at times to keep the books and furniture dry and in good condition especially during the wet or rainy season for all or mearly all of the houses are wet and damp during said season on my arrival at my post. I found the book and furinture in a bad condition as I mentioned my dispatch of the ult I am doing the best I can to save and preserve the book by butting them out in the sun and changing the place in the room for the care & on taking change of the post I found none of the articles mentioned and was compeled to furnish them for my - please instruct me on the subject
No 2. Inclosure

Rainfall &c on my arrival at the Legation November 17th 1890 - 6 AM it was raining and to date of this despatch I can say I think there has not been one 24 hours during these 27 days that there has not been a rain shower or pour down but as to quantity I can say as there is no rain guage here in Liberia now News paper published to keep one posted. THe weather has not been very lost but Sickley and a goodly number of funerals taken place during these 27 days up the River some 30 miles from Monrovia there is a case of small pox at one of the missions viz
I remain your obedient servant Alexander Clark US M
No 3 Inclosure
Please instruct me concerning my duty with referene to the answering letters from business forms or others & a sample of some attached to this inclosure viz: John Harrcmaker &c

No 4 Please instruct me with your desired form that my dispatch should be headed and send form to guide or govern me &c and should all my inclosures be signed officially as same as this dispatch containing said Inclosures as there is no forms in Legation.
I am your Obedient servant
Alexander Clark M. Resident & consul general.
5 Inclosure
NEW YORK MANCHESTER PHILADELPHIA BERLIN CHEMN
John Wanamaker per Str_______ JAMES PIKE Address Telegrams WANAMAKER - PARIS
Paris, September 30th, 1890. 18 8. CITE ROUGEMONT a 5. Rue Rougemont
To the Hon. United States Consul at Monrovia, Liberia,

My Dear Sir: Anxious for new ideas and to increase trade, may I trouble you to place me in communication with the best manufacturers in your District of goods suitable for export to the United States, or kindly have them catalogues and price lists, greatly obliging
Yours very truly, Rodman Wanamaker
(Dictated.)
